title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions related to the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in Chimayo, New Mexico, including transmission lines, pump stations, and reservoirs. Options for water supply sources will be considered, including connection to a regional water source or local sources. The Espanola Water Filtration Facility study will explore various water supply options, including regional, local, and recycled sources. It will also assess alternative water supplies like surface water and deep aquifer groundwater. The study will determine lifecycle costs, including operation, maintenance, and management expenses. The deadline for completion is within 3 years, with a 75 percent federal cost share. Coordination with relevant agencies will be ensured for the study. The Secretary will work with various agencies to conduct a feasibility study on water resources, including drilling exploratory wells on Bureau of Land Management land. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion. Additionally, the Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible entities in the study area, including activities like hauling water. The Secretary may provide assistance for activities such as hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, pump stations, and distribution pipelines. The Federal share of the cost for these activities will be 75 percent. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations for sections 102 and 103 for fiscal years 2005-2010. Funds under subsection (a)(1) cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of an Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico, including various projects to meet future water demands in the region. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of an Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico, including projects such as filtration facilities, finished water storage facilities, a booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and potable water transmission lines. The goal is to use reclaimed water to enhance groundwater and surface water supplies. The Federal share of the total cost of the facility and its components shall not exceed 25 percent, and funds provided by the Secretary cannot be used for operation or maintenance. SEC. 203. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,000,000 is authorized for the construction of the facility for fiscal years 2005 through 2009.
